docs.abstract: His clear prose, illuminating data and novel arguments, transformed debates around issues like public education and welfare reform.
docs.snippet: His clear prose, illuminating data and novel arguments, transformed debates around issues like public education and welfare reform.
docs.lead_paragraph: Christopher Jencks, a highly regarded sociologist who helped transform public and expert opinion on complex policy issues like homelessness, income inequality and racial gaps in standardized testing, died on Saturday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 88.

headline.main: Christopher Jencks, a Shaper of Views on Economic Inequality, Dies at 88
headline.print_headline: Christopher Jencks, 88; Shed New Light on Inequality

docs.abstract: New York City was on the front lines of the Covid-19 crisis. It has largely recovered, but has transformed into a place of greater extremes.
docs.snippet: New York City was on the front lines of the Covid-19 crisis. It has largely recovered, but has transformed into a place of greater extremes.
docs.lead_paragraph: New York City was on the front lines of the Covid-19 crisis. It has largely recovered, but has transformed into a place of greater extremes.

headline.main: How Has New York Remade Itself Since the Pandemic Arrived?

byline.original: By Stefanos Chen, Matthew Haag and Alex Lemonides

docs.abstract: We look at how the world changed — and what studies revealed about how we live.
docs.snippet: We look at how the world changed — and what studies revealed about how we live.
docs.lead_paragraph: When the pandemic upended our lives five years ago today, it gave researchers a rare chance to learn more about who we are and how we live. The entire world changed at once, creating natural experiments everywhere. What happens when sports teams play in empty stadiums? When the government sends people money? When women stop wearing high heels? When children stop going to school?

docs.abstract: What do fluctuating egg prices and ultraluxury restaurants have in common? They both fall under one Metro reporter’s beat.
docs.snippet: What do fluctuating egg prices and ultraluxury restaurants have in common? They both fall under one Metro reporter’s beat.
docs.lead_paragraph: As a reporter for The New York Times, Dionne Searcey has, as she put it, covered “a gazillion different things.”

headline.main: A Reporter With a Wealth of Knowledge on the Wealthy
headline.print_headline: A Writer With a Wealth of Knowledge on Wealth

docs.abstract: The economist Kimberly Clausing explains the possible costs and consequences of Trump’s tariffs.
docs.snippet: The economist Kimberly Clausing explains the possible costs and consequences of Trump’s tariffs.
docs.lead_paragraph: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

docs.abstract: Right-wing populism thrives on scarcity. The answer is abundance. But a politics of abundance will work only if Democrats confront where their approach has failed.
docs.snippet: Right-wing populism thrives on scarcity. The answer is abundance. But a politics of abundance will work only if Democrats confront where their approach has failed.
docs.lead_paragraph: I keep seeing Democrats say the resistance failed. On these pages, James Carville counseled Democrats to “roll over and play dead” until the Trump administration collapses beneath its own weight. Assuming corpse pose, Carville said, would be “a wiser approach than we pursued in the first Trump administration, when Democrats tried and failed at the art of resistance politics.”

headline.main: There Is a Liberal Answer to the Trump-Musk Wrecking Ball
headline.print_headline: There Is a Liberal Answer To the Trump-Musk Alliance

docs.abstract: The president has repeatedly made false or misleading claims in pursuing an aggressive agenda in the first weeks of his second term.
docs.snippet: The president has repeatedly made false or misleading claims in pursuing an aggressive agenda in the first weeks of his second term.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Trump will address Congress on Tuesday night to sell his vision for his second administration, as he remakes American government and tests the limits of executive power.

headline.main: Fact-Checking Trump’s Claims on Tariffs, Ukraine and DOGE

docs.abstract: Bong Joon Ho has turned his funny-sad excavations of life under capitalism into unlikely blockbusters. With “Mickey 17,” he’s bending a whole new genre.
docs.snippet: Bong Joon Ho has turned his funny-sad excavations of life under capitalism into unlikely blockbusters. With “Mickey 17,” he’s bending a whole new genre.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bong Joon Ho sent a text message a bit past noon, naming a subway station in Seoul and asking me to meet him there at 7 p.m. In his imperfect English, he signed off with a cryptic tease: “I’ll show you some ordinary but strange area. See you in front of GATE No. 4.”

headline.main: The ‘Parasite’ Director Brings Class Warfare to Outer Space

docs.abstract: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has jumped into the New York City mayoral race. His first proposal focuses on affordability.
docs.snippet: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has jumped into the New York City mayoral race. His first proposal focuses on affordability.
docs.lead_paragraph: When former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo joined the New York City mayoral race over the weekend, he reintroduced himself to New Yorkers after years out of the public eye.

headline.main: Cuomo’s First Mayoral Campaign Promise: A Plan to Tackle Affordability
headline.print_headline: Cuomo Promises a Plan to Tackle Affordability

docs.abstract: Zero-sum thinking has spread like a mind virus, from geopolitics to pop culture.
docs.snippet: Zero-sum thinking has spread like a mind virus, from geopolitics to pop culture.
docs.lead_paragraph: My grandfather’s idea of an Easter egg hunt involved hiding money in colorful plastic eggs sprinkled around his house on Long Island. Most held coins, but there was always one with a crisp, new $100 bill.

headline.main: Welcome to the Zero Sum Era. Now How Do We Get Out?
